content:
This is completely impossible to solve in 5 minutes.
Solving in 15 would require someone who has done this before or someone who has looked up a solution online.

There is no way this is a fun clash.

Your own code is 37 lines when you properly indent it (removing the semi-colon and colon hacks that allowed you to golf it to 27 lines).

Even knowing your whole solution, I doubt you could re-write it from scratch in 10 minutes. Expecting people to solve this in 15 minutes is madness. Clashes are meant to be feasibly solvable in 5 minutes.

This should have been a puzzle, not a clash. I feel terrible for anyone who gets this as a clash. Even reading the description will take 4-5 minutes. Then figuring out where to start and trying it out will take up to 10, there's no time for debugging if anything goes wrong... This is just not fair, I can't believe no one rejected it...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very simple. It can be solved very quickly.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a classical problem, solvable with recursion in less than 10 lines of python (see wikipedia)

Title
* Why "hacked"?

Goal section
* Suggest to change "Extra" to "Hint".

Cases
* There are two validators on n = 4. Please revise the cases so that they are not duplicated.

Game modes/type
* Probably more suited to be a puzzle than a clash. For reference, there is already a puzzle on Tower of Hanoi:
https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/hanoi-tower

Thanks.
Pretty impossible for a clash of code and for a beginner.
I assure this is a hard puzzle to get through

I have fixed the above things
-Hacked-->Solution
-Extra-->Hint
-Duplicate Validator removed

Should I delete this from here and contribute in Puzzles?

It took me 25 minutes just now after lots of preparation and thinking and reading. I'm usually in the top 30 clash of code players. This just does not seem like a good level of difficulty for a clash, and anyone who approved this saying it was easy just sounds like someone who wanted to show off.

My solution in Ruby:

# https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tower_of_Hanoi#Iterative_solution
n = gets.to_i
d = n.even? ? 1 : -1 # Direction the smallest piece moves
x = [[*1..n],[],[]]
c = 0
i = 0 # Location of smallest piece
f = -> (i, j){ [i,j].map{"ABC"[_1]}*"--->" }
until x == [[],[],[*1..n]] || c > 2**n
  if c.even?
    # Move smallest piece
    j = (i + d) % 3   # Next location
    puts f[i,j]
    x[i] -= [1] # Remove smallest piece from tower i
    x[j] = [1] + x[j] # Add it to tower j
    i = j   # Update smallest piece location
  else
    # Move non-smallest piece
    m = (x.map(&:first)-[1,nil]).min  # Next smallest top piece
    k = (0..2).find{x[_1][0]==m}   # It's current location
    j = (0..2).find{x[_1][0]!=m && x[_1][0]!=1}   # Next location
    puts f[k,j]
    x[k] -= [m] # Remove non-smallest piece from tower i
    x[j] = [m] + x[j] # Add it to tower j
  end
  c += 1
end

I am extremely sorry.. Actually I am new to this platform, and someone suggested this thing already, and I have infact asked him/her if I should remove this, and he/she asked me to wait, and so I did.. But sorry again, since it's already approved I am not removing this.. please cooperate..

Yes, I just got this as a clash today and quite a few people solved it. Sorry for my reaction, this is actually a good clash if you know the trick (recursion!). :)

I didn't realise the recursive solution is actually quite short compared to your one.
I think most of the people who solved it in the clash ended up finding a solution online and translating it into their language, which is not ideal, but it's at least possible to solve in 5 minutes once you know the recursive solution's basic concepts.

Someone even solved it in about 4 minutes, which shocked me. :)
I think I didn't realise this is a well-known problem for studying recursive algorithms.
Solving it without recursion is extremely hard though, as I found out.

Recursive solution in Ruby:
n = gets.to_i
def hanoi(n, to, from, other)
  return if n == 0
  # first move n-1 from 'to' to 'other'
  hanoi(n-1, other, from, to)
  # now move the nth piece
  puts "#{from}--->#{to}"
  # now move the n-1 back from 'other' to the target
  hanoi(n-1, to, other, from)
end
hanoi(n, "C", "A", "B")

Thanks for fixing the issues.

You may wait for more comments before making a decision.
Ok, and thanks for your suggestions.
